speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Good afternoon.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: At the Federal Reserve, we are strongly committed to achieving the monetary policy goals that Congress has given us—maximum employment and price stability.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Since the beginning of the pandemic, we have taken forceful actions to provide relief and stability, to ensure that the recovery will be as strong as possible, and to limit lasting damage to the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Today my colleagues on the FOMC and I reaffirmed our strong forward guidance for interest rates and also provided additional guidance for our asset purchases.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Together, these measures will ensure that monetary policy will continue to deliver powerful support to the economy until the recovery is complete.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Economic activity has continued to recover from its depressed second-quarter level.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The substantial reopening of the economy led to a rapid rebound in activity, and real GDP rose at an annual rate of 33 percent in the third quarter.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In recent months, however, the pace of improvement has moderated.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Household spending on goods, especially durable goods, has been strong and has moved above its pre-pandemic level.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In contrast, spending on services remains low, especially in sectors that typically require people to gather closely, including travel and hospitality.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The overall rebound in household spending owes in part to federal stimulus payments and expanded unemployment benefits, which provided essential support to many families and individuals.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The housing sector has fully recovered from the downturn, supported in part by low mortgage interest rates.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Business investment has also picked up.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The recovery has progressed more quickly than generally expected, and forecasts from FOMC participants for economic growth this year have been revised up since our September Summary of Economic Projections.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Even so, overall economic activity remains well below its level before the pandemic, and the path ahead remains highly uncertain.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In the labor market, more than half of the 22 million jobs that were lost in March and April have been regained, as many people were able to return to work.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As with overall economic activity, the pace of improvement in the labor market has moderated.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Job growth slowed to 245,000 in November, and while the unemployment rate has continued to decline, it remains elevated at 6.7 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Participation in the labor market remains notably below pre-pandemic levels.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Although there has been much progress in the labor market since the spring, we will not lose sight of the millions of Americans who remain out of work.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Looking ahead, FOMC participants project the unemployment rate to continue to decline; the median projection is 5 percent at the end of next year and moves below 4 percent by 2023.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The economic downturn has not fallen equally on all Americans, and those least able to shoulder the burden have been the hardest hit.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In particular, the high level of joblessness has been especially severe for lower-wage workers in the service sector and for African Americans and Hispanics.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The economic dislocation has upended many lives and created great uncertainty about the future.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The pandemic has also left a significant imprint on inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Following large declines in the spring, consumer prices picked up over the summer but have leveled out more recently.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: For those sectors that have been most adversely affected by the pandemic, prices remain particularly soft.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Overall, on a 12-month basis, inflation remains below our 2 percent longer-run objective.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The median inflation projection from FOMC participants rises from 1.2 percent this year to 1.8 percent next year and reaches 2 percent in 2023.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As we have emphasized throughout the pandemic, the outlook for the economy is extraordinarily uncertain and will depend in large part on the course of the virus.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Recent news on vaccines has been very positive.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: However, significant challenges and uncertainties remain with regard to the timing, production, and distribution of vaccines as well as their efficacy across December 16, 2020 different groups.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It remains difficult to assess the timing and scope of the economic implications Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL of these developments.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The ongoing surge in new COVID-19 cases, both here in the United States and abroad, is particularly concerning, and the next few months are likely to be very challenging.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: All of us have a role to play in our nation’s response to the pandemic.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Following the advice of public health professionals to keep appropriate social distances and to wear masks in public will help get the economy back to full strength.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: A full economic recovery is unlikely until people are confident that it is safe to engage—reengage in a broad range of activities.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As we previously announced, we are now releasing the entire package of our SEP materials at the same time as our FOMC statement.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Included in these materials are two new exhibits that show how the balance of participants’ assessments of uncertainty and risks have evolved over time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Since the onset of the pandemic, nearly all participants continue to judge the level of uncertainty about the economic outlook as elevated.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In terms of risks to the outlook, fewer participants see the balance of risks as weighted to the downside than in September.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: While a little more than half of participants now judge risks to be broadly balanced for economic activity, a similar number continue to see risks weighted to the downside for inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The Fed’s response to this crisis has been guided by our mandate to promote maximum employment and stable prices for the American people, along with our responsibilities to promote the stability of the financial system.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As noted in our Statement on Longer-Run Goals and Monetary Policy Strategy, we view maximum employment as a broad-based and inclusive goal.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Our ability to achieve maximum employment in the years ahead depends importantly on having longer-term inflation expectations well anchored at 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As we reiterated in today’s statement, with inflation running persistently below 2 percent, we will aim to achieve inflation moderately above 2 percent for some time so that inflation averages 2 percent over time and December 16, 2020 longer-term inflation expectations remain well anchored at 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We expect to maintain an Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL accommodative stance of monetary policy until these employment and inflation outcomes are achieved.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: With regard to interest rates, we continue to expect it will be appropriate to maintain the current 0 to ¼ percent target range for the federal funds rate until labor market conditions have reached levels consistent with the Committee’s assessment of maximum employment and inflation has risen to 2 percent and is on track to moderately exceed 2 percent for some time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In addition, as we noted in today’s policy statement, we will continue to increase our holdings of Treasury securities by at least $80 billion per month and of agency mortgage-backed securities by at least $40 billion per month until substantial further progress has been made toward our maximum-employment and price-stability goals.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We believe the increase in our balance sheet this year has materially eased financial conditions and is providing substantial support to the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Combined with our forward guidance for the federal funds rate, our enhanced balance sheet guidance will ensure that the stance of monetary policy remains highly accommodative as the recovery progresses.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Our guidance is outcome based and is tied to progress toward reaching our employment and inflation goals.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Thus, if progress toward our goals were to slow, the guidance would convey our intention to increase policy accommodation through a lower expected path of the federal funds rate and a higher expected path of the balance sheet.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Overall, our interest rate and balance sheet tools are providing powerful support to the economy and will continue to do so.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The Federal Reserve has also been taking broad and forceful actions to more directly support the flow of credit in the economy for households, for businesses large and small, and for state and local governments.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Preserving the flow of credit is essential for mitigating damage to December 16, 2020 the economy and promoting a robust recovery.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Many of our programs rely on emergency Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL lending powers that require the support of the Treasury Department and are available only in very unusual circumstances, such as those we find ourselves in today.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: These programs serve as a backstop to key credit markets and have helped to restore the flow of credit from private lenders through normal channels.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We have deployed these lending powers to an unprecedented extent, enabled in large part by financial backing and support from Congress and the Treasury.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Although funds from the CARES Act will not be available to support new loans or new purchases after—of assets after December 31, the Treasury could authorize support for emerging lending facilities, if needed, through the Exchange Stabilization Fund.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: When the time comes, after the crisis has passed, we will put these emergency tools back in the box.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As I have emphasized before, these are lending powers, not spending powers.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The Fed cannot grant money to particular beneficiaries.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We can only create programs or facilities with broad-based eligibility to make loans to solvent entities with the expectation that the loans will be repaid.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Many borrowers are benefiting from these programs, as is the overall economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But for many others, getting a loan that may be difficult to repay may not be the answer.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In these cases, direct fiscal support may be needed.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Elected officials have the power to tax and spend and to make decisions about where we, as a society, should direct our collective resources.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The fiscal policy actions that have been taken thus far have made a critical difference to families, businesses, and communities across the country.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Even so, the current economic downturn is the most severe of our lifetimes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It will take a while to get back to the levels of economic activity and employment that prevailed at the beginning of this year, and it may take continued support from both monetary and fiscal policy to achieve that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: To conclude, we understand that our actions affect communities, families, and businesses across the country.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Everything we do is in service to our public mission.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We are committed to using our full range of tools to support the economy and to help assure that the recovery from this difficult period will be as robust as possible.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I look forward to your questions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Yes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Well, so we’re not—we’re not going to be identifying specific—associating that test with, with specific numbers at this point.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, really, the overarching message, Rich, is that our guidance for both interest rates and asset purchases will keep monetary policy accommodative until our maximum-employment and price-stability goals are achieved, and that’s, that’s a powerful message.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So “substantial further progress” means what it says.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It means we’ll be looking for employment to be substantially closer to assessments of its maximum level and inflation to be substantially closer to our 2 percent longer-run goal before we start making adjustments to our purchases.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I would also point out that by increasing our asset holdings, we see ourselves as adding policy accommodation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There will come a time when the economy does not require increasing amounts of policy accommodation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And when that time comes—and that will be uncertain and, in any case, is, is some ways off.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I can’t give you an exact set of numbers.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We will—of December 16, 2020 course, as we approach that point, we’ll be evaluating that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And when we see ourselves on a Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL path to achieve that goal, then we will—we will say so undoubtedly well in advance of any time when we would actually consider gradually tapering the pace of purchases.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, you know, again, I would start with what we actually did at the meeting, which, which was, we provided this, this guidance about the path of asset purchases.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I just went through what, what they—what they—the guidance that we put forward.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, so I guess since September we’ve now adopted a flexible average inflation-targeting framework.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We have provided rate guidance that is tightly linked to the goals as expressed in that new framework.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And now we’ve done the same for, for asset purchases.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, you know, we’ve, we’ve been sort of—as, as the future has become clearer and as we’ve absorbed new developments in medical—in the medical sphere and also in, in the economy, we have—began to be able to see further.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we’ve, we’ve started to be able to provide further important guidance.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we think that the—that the asset purchase guidance, guidance is very important.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We think that the, the prior language of “in coming months” was obviously temporary.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: This links that guidance, those purchases, to actual “substantial further progress” toward our, our mandated goals.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We think that’s important.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we think that that is important to have done.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I, I would just add, though, that we also continue to think that our current policy stance is appropriate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We think it’s providing a great deal of support for the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Financial conditions are highly accommodative.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, we monitor a range of financial condition indexes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There are many of them, and they’ll, they’ll all pretty much tell you that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: December 16, 2020 You can—you can also look at the interest sensitive parts of the economy—for example, Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL housing, durable sales, vehicle sales—those parts of the economy are, are performing very, very well.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The parts of the economy that are weak are the service-sector businesses that involve close contact.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Those are not being held back by financial conditions, but rather by the spread of the virus.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I’ll close by, by just saying, we do have the flexibility to provide more accommodation through the channel you mentioned and through other channels.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we recognize that circumstances could shift in a way that warrants our, our doing that, including by adjusting purchases.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We are committed to using our full range of tools to support the U.S. economy to achieve our goals.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We will continue to use our tools to support the economy for as long as it takes until the job is well and truly done.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: No one should doubt that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Well, Nick, I—on, on the first part of the question, I, I don’t—I wouldn’t want to sort of talk about hypothetical situations.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We do that at every meeting.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we look at where financial conditions are now, December 16, 2020 and, and we, we feel that they are appropriate for now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Anytime we feel like the economy could, Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL could use stronger accommodation, we would be prepared to provide it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We—but right now, we’re providing a great deal, and we think—we happen to think it’s the right amount.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, you, you mentioned—I think you’re referring to the idea of maintaining the duration but, but reducing the quantity, which is sort of what the Bank of Canada did.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that, that is something that we—you know, that we talked about in the last meeting and was addressed in the minutes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I would say, the views on that were mixed: Some thought it was an interesting idea, others not so much.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I, I wouldn’t say that that’s something that’s, that’s high on our list of, of possibilities.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So on your—on your first question, we really have not thought about that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re, we’re very focused on—we have a lot to do now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We, we have not focused on, on that question, and I, I really have nothing to add on that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Your second question is—sorry.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Oh, if there were no—yes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: No, we, we would have the ability—certainly, we would have the ability to do facilities under 13(3) in some cases with no backing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But we did some facilities—I think one of Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL our facilities this time didn’t have any Treasury backing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I think some in the—in the round of—during the Global Financial Crisis also didn’t have any.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I would say that we are—you know, we’re—we have the authorities we have.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We will use them if, if they’re needed and if—and if the law permits us to do so.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We would—we would always do that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We, we do not have any plans for, for the future about this.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We—we’re very focused on, on getting through year-end.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ve been very focused on, on the issues that are right in front of us.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, honestly, we’re not—we’re not planning on anything or having any discussions about what we might do down the road.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Okay.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So on, on fiscal policy, I would just say a couple of things.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The case for fiscal policy right now is, is very, very strong.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I think that is widely understood, I would say, now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The details of it are entirely up to Congress.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But with the December 16, 2020 expiration of unemployment benefits—some of the unemployment benefits, the expiration of Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL eviction moratoriums with the virus spreading the way it is, there’s a need for households and businesses to have, have fiscal support.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I do think that—again, I think that is widely understood.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I think it would be—I, I certainly would welcome the work that Congress is doing right now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s not up to us to judge that work.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s really, really theirs.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I, I don’t have a view for you on, on the size of it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s—you know, it’s obviously a substantial bill.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: On the surge, you know, so it’s a really interesting question.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We have, and others too, have consistently expected there to be more economic—that, that cases would hold—growth in cases would hold back the economy more than it actually has.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we’ve overestimated the, the effects on the economy of, of these spikes we’ve been having.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Now, this spike is so much larger that I think—and I think forecasters generally do think that there—that this will have an effect on suppressing activity, particularly activity that involves people getting together in bars and restaurants, on airplanes and hotels and things like that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And you’re starting to see that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In the—in the high-frequency data, you’re now beginning to see that show up.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I think if this is—the case numbers are so high and so widespread across the country that that, that seems like it must happen.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We don’t—we don’t really know.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, there are—there are a lot of estimates.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The general expectation is, you’re seeing some slowing now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And you’ll see the first quarter could well be—what, what we said is that coming months are going to be challenging.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The first quarter will, will certainly show significant effects from this.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: At the same time, people are getting vaccinated now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They’re getting vaccinated.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And by the end of the first quarter into the second quarter, you’re going to be seeing significant numbers of people vaccinated.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Again, we don’t have any experience with this.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You have to think that sometime in the Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL middle of next year, you will—you will see people feeling comfortable going out and engaging in a broader range of activities.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And some people will be probably quick to do that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, nonetheless, my expectation—and I think many people have the expectation that the second half of next year should—the economy should be performing strongly.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We should be—you know, we should be getting people back to work.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Businesses should be reopening and that kind of thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The issue is more the next four or five months—getting through the next four, five, six months.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That is key.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, and, you know, clearly there’s going to be need for help there.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, and, you know, my sense and hope is that we’ll be getting that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, so we monitor basically just about every asset price in the economy, and housing prices are something that we’ve been monitoring.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And you see them moving up.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You see very high demand.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: This, this is the housing market that people have been expecting since, you know, 2010.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, and then, you know, not many, when the—when the pandemic hit, thought, “Oh, this is what—this is what will produce that housing market,” but it has.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Now, I would say, from a financial stability standpoint, housing prices are not—are not of a level of concern right now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s just reflective of a lot of demand.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, builders are going to bring forth supply.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There’s also a sense that this—some of this may be pent-up demand from when the economy was closed, which would imply that demand—once that demand is met, that the real level of demand will be more manageable.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So it’s a—it’s a healthy economy now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We, we met recently with a bunch of homebuilders, and many of them in the business 30, 40 years said they’ve never seen the likes of it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, no, housing prices themselves are not—are not a financial stability concern at the moment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We will watch that carefully.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But in the near term, I wouldn’t think that that’s an issue that we’d be concerned about.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There is more that we can do, certainly.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We can—we can expand our, our asset purchase programs.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We can focus them more on the longer end.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There are a number of options we would have to provide more support to the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I would—I would say, though, that in the near term, the help that people need isn’t just from low interest rates that stimulates demand over time and works with long and variable lags.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s really support.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As the—as—we’ve, we’ve talked about this as all of these government December 16, 2020 policies trying to work together to create a bridge across this chasm, economic chasm that was Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL created by the pandemic.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And for many Americans, that bridge is there and, and they’re across it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But there’s a group for, for which they, they don’t have a bridge yet.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s who we’re talking about here.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s, it’s the 10 million people who lost their jobs.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s people who may lose their homes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s—you know, you see the, the—many, many millions of Americans are, are waiting in food lines in their cars these days all over the country.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we know there’s need out there.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We know there are small businesses all over the country that, that have been basically unable to really function, and they’re just hanging on.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So—and, and they’re, they’re so critical to our economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So—and, by the way, now that we can—we can kind of see the light at the end of the tunnel, it would be—it would be bad to see, you know, people losing their business, their life’s work in many cases, or even generations’ worth of work, because they couldn’t last another few months, which is what it amounts to.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we have more we can do.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’ll—I, I think more the issue is, we’re going to need to continue to provide support to this economy for quite a period of time, because the, the economy will be growing in expectation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We should be growing at a fairly healthy clip by the second half of next year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But it’s going to be a while before we really are back to the levels of, of labor market—the, the sort of conditions in the labor market that we had in early this year and for much of the last couple of years.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s how I think about it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, in terms of the vaccine, yes, you know, we do estimates of, of when the United States would reach herd immunity, and they’re, they’re going to be similar to what other people think.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, it depends on your assumptions, such as how many people will actually take the vaccine and how fast will the rollout be.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So it’s assumption based on assumption based on assumption.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, you know, sometime—it’s possible sometime in the middle or second half of next year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I’m not going to try to be precise, because it’s just another estimate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, our people are very good, but they’re looking at, at the same data as other people are.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so, you know, all the estimates are—it depends on what your assumptions are.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But under a normal set of assumptions, it could happen as, as soon as the middle of next year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In terms of the, you know, inflation, a couple things—your second question.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, we’re—I think you have to be honest with yourself about, about inflation these days.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There are—there are significant disinflationary pressures around the world, and there have been for a while, and they persist today.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s, is not going to be easy to have inflation move up.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And it isn’t going to be just a question—it’s going to take some time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It took a long time to get inflation back to 2 percent in the last crisis.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, we’re, we’re honest with ourselves and with you in the SEP that even with the very high level of accommodation that we’re providing both through low rates and very high levels of asset purchases, it will take some time, because that’s what we believe the underlying inflation dynamics are in our economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s sort of why we’re—one reason why we’re concerned about inflation is that we see that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, and that’s why we have adopted the flexible average inflation-targeting framework.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s why we’re aiming for an overshoot.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But we’re, we’re honest with ourselves and with the public that it will take some time to get there.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In terms of, you know, would, would it really speed it up a lot to, to move asset purchases, you know, I don’t think that would really be—I think it’s going to take a long time however you do it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, we’ve been having very long expansions since—in, in the last several decades because inflation has not—really, the old model was, inflation would come along and the Fed would tighten, and we’d have a recession.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Now inflation has been low, and we haven’t had that dynamic.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And the result has been three of the four longest expansions in, in modern history, in recorded history.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, you know, we’re, we’re thinking that this could be another long expansion, and that we’ll keep our—what we’re saying is, we’re going to keep policy highly accommodative until the expansion is well down the tracks.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’re not going to preemptively raise rates until we see inflation actually reaching 2 percent and being on track to exceed 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s a very strong commitment, and we think that’s the right place to be.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I’m just going to add, markets have actually found this fairly credible.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: If you look at what—at inflation compensation and at the survey measures of, of when the Fed will lift off, everything has moved.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There have been significant movements since we announced the framework in the direction that is consistent with the—with the framework being credible to market participants.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I, I don’t think it’s something that—I, I mean, I’m actually pleased by, by the reception it’s gotten in markets.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And markets have moved in ways that suggest it is credible.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So the—you’re, you’re talking about the—sorry, the Network [of Central Banks and Supervisors] for Greening the Financial System, which we joined this week.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I’ll just—I’ll just say a couple things about that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, first, I’ll just start by saying that we’re going to move carefully and thoughtfully on developing an understanding of how climate change affects our work, including the areas you mentioned.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re going to do so with a great deal of engagement with all of our external constituencies, including the public and their elected representatives who are charged with our oversight.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ll do it with great transparency.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Remember that we are a nonpolitical agency whose goals and authorities to achieve those goals are set by Congress.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We have great responsibilities and strong authorities that we’ll use vigorously.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re not the forum where all the great issues of the day are to be hashed out, debated, and addressed unless and only to the extent that those issues are directly relevant to our statutory goals and are addressable through our legal authorities.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And because we have a narrow remit, and because we stick to it, Congress has given us a precious grant of independence from direct political control.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So society’s broad response to climate change is for others to decide—in particular, elected leaders.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But—so let me—let me get to your question.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So Congress hasn’t explicitly assigned us or other financial regulators a role, and we’re not among the agencies who contribute to the National Climate Assessment—Climate Assessment, for example.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But climate change is nonetheless relevant to our existing mandates under the law.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And let me tell you why.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: One of our jobs is to regulate and supervise banks and to look after the stability of the financial system.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s a responsibility we share with other agencies.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The public will expect that we will—we will do that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we’ll, we’ll expect that, that those important institutions will be resilient against the many resists—risks that they fake—face: credit risk, market risk, cyber risk.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Climate change is an emerging risk to financial institutions, the financial system, and the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we are, as so many others are, in the very early stages of understanding what that means, what needs to be done about it, and by whom.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s why 83 central banks have joined together to share research and identify best practices in this important emerging area.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ve been attending NGFS meetings as an observer for more than a year, taking part in the work.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We had discussed that it was probably time to join as a member.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I’ll just say that the financial system is really a global one.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s important that we work and discuss best practices with peer agencies around the world, especially in a field where we’re just beginning to develop our, our understanding.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You asked about monetary policy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, I—I’ll say this.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We, we have historically shied away strongly from taking a role in credit allocation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In fact, our agreement with Treasury during the financial crisis from back in 2009 or ’10 says that we will avoid credit allocation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s something we’ve carefully avoided.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I, I would be very reluctant to see us move in that direction, picking one area as creditworthy and another not.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So you asked about monetary policy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, it’s, it’s—for now, I would say the real—the real concern is—the real place to focus, for me, is supervision of financial institutions and then financial stability concerns.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You can see a connection there.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Monetary policy, maximum employment, stable prices—it’s less obvious to me.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I can—I can, you know—I can make the argument, but it’s less obvious to me that those should be first-order things that we would look at in connection with climate change.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But I think there’s—I think there’s work to be done to understand the connection between climate change and the strength and resilience of financial markets and financial institutions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think that work is in its early days.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, again, we’ll be careful.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ll be thorough and transparent and, and engage with the public on all that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Okay.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So the state and local governments, they provide important critical services: safety, fire, police, health, all kinds of things like that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They’re, they’re really involved in people’s lives, state and local governments are, to, to a large extent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, they’re in the middle of these discussions, and, and those, those are issues for them to decide.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I would say that the picture is mixed.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: What’s happened is, if you’re a state that has a significant exposure to tourism or to extracting energy from the ground—oil from the ground, or gas—you are probably, at least in those industries, feeling a significant loss of revenue.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: A number of other states have been surprised on the upside, where—and that’s because goods sales, for example—property taxes are—don’t move much year to year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, the kind of sales taxes on goods—goods sales have been very high.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Income has been more or less replaced by, by the CARES Act—fully replaced, more than, in many cases.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So the concerns that we had at the very beginning of really serious, deep shortfalls and massive budget cuts on the part of state and local governments have not yet—have not yet occurred.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: What we’re seeing is, is that it’s different state to state.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And some states are having significant difficulties, others not so much.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The real concern, though, that still emerges is, state and local governments are very large employers, and—one of the largest.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so far, since the pandemic began, employment has December 16, 2020 dropped by 1.3 million in—of state and local government.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So it’s, it’s a very large number of Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL people to be—to be out of work from just that one source.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s actually significantly more than lost their jobs during the Global Financial Crisis.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that is—that is a significant—a significant part of that group is, is in education.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So when the schools reopen, a significant part of that 1.3 million would go back to work.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Nonetheless, it’s a concern.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re, we’re watching carefully to understand why that—why that many people have been let go and what are—really are the sources.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we’re monitoring it carefully, and it’s a mixed picture.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I, I just have to leave the question of what to do with fiscal policy on this to Congress.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Right.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I, I could go back, James, to what I said earlier, which is, this is—this is a very, very large asset purchase program.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s providing a tremendous amount of, of support for the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: If you look at the interest-sensitive parts of the economy, they’re performing very well.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The parts that are not performing well are not struggling from high December 16, 2020 interest rates.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They’re struggling from exposure to, to COVID, in a sense.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: These are—these are Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL the businesses that, that are really hit hard by people’s reluctance to gather closely.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, so we, we do have the ability to—you know, to buy more bonds or to buy longer-term bonds.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL

speaker: CHAIR POWELL

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But also, I would remind—I would also note, though, monetary policy works with “long and variable lags,” is the famous statement.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we think that the big effects from monetary policy are, you know, months and months into the future.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So this looks like a—you know, it looks like a time when what is really needed is fiscal policy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, and that’s why it is, is a very positive thing that, that we’re getting that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we, we remain open to doing—you know, to, to either increasing the size of our asset purchases, if that turns out to be appropriate, or to just moving the maturities, moving to buying longer maturities, because that had—that also increases accommodation by taking more duration risk out of the market.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But we think our current stance is appropriate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we think that our—you know, that our, our guidance on asset purchases today will also provide support to the economy over time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Again, what we’ve—what we’ve done is, we’ve laid out a path whereby we’re going to keep monetary policy highly accommodative for a long time, really until—really until we reach very close to our goals, which is not, you know, not really the way it’s been done in the past.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s, that’s providing significant support for the economy now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We don’t think the economy suffers from a lack of, of highly accommodative financial conditions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We think it’s suffering from the pandemic and people wanting to not engage in certain kinds of economic activity.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we expect that, that with the virus, that that will improve—that condition will improve.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Nonetheless, again, we will—are prepared to use our December 16, 2020 tools, and we will use them at such time and in such amounts as we—as we think would, Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL would help.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that, that has all the markings of a transient increase in the price level.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But what inflation is, is a process whereby they go up year upon year upon year upon year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And if—given the inflation dynamics that we’ve had over the last several decades, just a single, single sort of price-level increase has not resulted in ongoing price-level increases.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that, that was—the problem back in the 1970s was, it was the combination of two things.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: One, when unemployment went down and resources got tight, prices started going up.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But the second problem was that that—that that increase was persistent, there was a level of persistence.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So if prices went up 6 percent this year, they’d go up 6 percent next year, because people would internalize.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I mean, really, really, that’s what happens is, people internalize that they can raise prices, and that it’s okay to pay prices that are going up at that rate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that was the inflation—those are the inflation dynamics of that era.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Those dynamics are not in place anymore.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There—the connection between low unemployment or other resource utilization and inflation is so much weaker than it was.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s still there, but it’s a—it’s a faint heartbeat compared to what it was.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And the persistence of inflation, if you—if you get a—for example, oil prices go up, and that’ll send a temporary shock through the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The persistence of that into, into inflation over time is just not there.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So they—what you describe may happen, and, of course, we would watch it very carefully.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We, we understand that we will always be learning new things from the economy about how it will behave in certain cases.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But I would—I would expect, though, going in that that would be a one-time price increase rather than an increase in underlying inflation that would be persistent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: No, no.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Definitely not.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Right.

sentence: So—you were breaking up a little.

sentence: I think—I think I got the sense of it, though.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Yes, I, I don’t think it’s at all a foregone conclusion that there needs to be a December 16, 2020 permanent Fed presence.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, there’s lots of demand for, for U.S. Treasury paper all—from all over the world.

sentence: And I, I think we need to be thoughtful about the structure of the Treasury market and look at ways to make sure that the capacity is there for it to be handled by the private sector.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think the main thing that those companies need is a—is a robust recovery—a strong, robust recovery.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, and I think my understanding is that there’s support for small businesses in, in what’s being discussed on Capitol Hill.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I would certainly think that would be something well worth looking at.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, you know, we’ve had a—and I’ve had sort of the typical meetings with the transition team for Treasury.

sentence: So, you know, financial stability—we, we look at a broad range of things.

sentence: We actually have a framework so that we can, you know, be—evaluate changes in financial stability over time, and so that the public can evaluate whether we’re doing a job—a good job at it.

sentence: And, you know, we published a report a few weeks ago on that—maybe it was month or so ago.
